caption: Well-dressed anti-Wallace protester attends the Wallace-for-president rally.
alt_text: Close-up of an African-American man with a white police office standing behind him at the Wallace-for-president rally in Durham.

caption: A black policeman stands in the midst of the crowd at Durham 's Wallace-for-president rally.
alt_text: A group of men at the with the camera focused on the face of an African-American police officer.

caption: A policeman approaches a man in the crowd during the Wallace-for-president rally in Durham.
alt_text: An African-American police officer works on crowd control at the Wallace-for-president rally at the Durham police headquarters. A protest sign in the background says "Labor Stands Up for Wallace."

caption: A young anti-Wallace protester makes his voice heard at Durham 's Wallace-for-president rally.
alt_text: Close-up of an African-American man standing in a crowd with his arm raised in the air.

caption: The 1968 Wallace-for-President rally brought out many supporters of the former Alabama governor, including this couple who drove up to Durham from Sanford.
alt_text: A man and woman standing in front of a George Wallace campaign car.

caption: Supporters and opponents of former Alabama governor George Wallace clash at a 1968 Wallace-for-President rally at Durham police headquarters.
alt_text: A large crowd of people with signs. Some police officers in riot gear visible.

caption: Wallace supporters at Wallace-for-president rally at the Durham police headquarters.
alt_text: Three women in stars and stripes dresses wearing George Wallace sashes.

caption: Policeman at Wallace-for-president rally at the Durham police headquarters.
alt_text: An African-American police officer. In the background two people are standing on a roof.

caption: Anti-Wallace protesters with gas masks at Wallace-for-president rally at the Durham police headquarters.
alt_text: Two men with gas masks, one covering his face and the other on top of his head.

caption: 250 employees, students, and faculty protest in front of the Duke Administration Building on April 19, 1967.
alt_text: A line of protestors with signs marching on Duke's campus. In the foreground are African-American women and in the background are some white male students.

caption: Employees, students, and faculty protest in front of the Duke Administration Building on April 19, 1967.
alt_text: A line of protestors carrying signs on Duke's campus.

caption: Oliver Harvey and unidentified student distribute literature about employee issues in April 1967.
alt_text: Two white men stand at an information table. A white male student and Oliver Harvey are behind the table.

caption: Founder Howard Fuller talks to a student in front of Malcolm X Liberation University, the alternative university in downtown Durham founded in protest of Duke's racial climate.
alt_text: Howard Fuller and an unidentified student stand in front of a building with a sign that reads "Malcom X Liberation University."

caption: Heavy police guard accompanies students on the second day of protest in response to the killings at South Carolina State College in Orangeburg , S.C.
alt_text: A large group of people in the street. Most people in the image are police in riot gear with their backs to the camera.

caption: Students with protest signs vent anger at black police in response to the killings at South Carolina State College in Orangeburg, South Carolina.
alt_text: A long line of protestors holding signs. A sign for the US Air Force Recruiting Station is visible.

caption: Students march in double file from North Carolina College to Durham's Five Points during the protests in response to killings at South Carolina State College in Orangeburg, South Carolina.
alt_text: A police officer directing traffic with a large group of protestors in the background.

caption: Protest signs equate police violence with Klan violence during the protests in response to killings at South Carolina State College in Orangeburg, South Carolina.
alt_text: A protest sign that shows the shape of a star with the words "They have replaced sheets with badges" on the sign.

caption: Police downtown during Orangeburg sympathy protest.
alt_text: Two police officers in riot gear stand outside a storefront.

caption: Student protestors downtown during Orangeburg sympathy protest.
alt_text: A group of African-American protestors. One person holds a sign that says "End Police Brutality."

caption: Duke students' silent vigil after assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.
alt_text: A large crowd gathered on Duke's campus. In the foreground one white man stands with a sign that says "Silent Vigil in Memory of Martin Luther King."

caption: Black students leave the campus after vacating the Allen Administration Building in the wake of its takeover to protest the campus racial climate.
alt_text: A large group of primarily African-American people with the Duke Chapel in the background. They carry a banner that reads "Malcolm X Liberation School."

caption: Students inside Allen Building talk with students on the outside during demonstration at Duke when students took over the Allen Building on February 13, 1969.
alt_text: Two African-American people inside a building peer through a window.
attribution: Harold Moore, Durham Morning Herald.  Permission to use this image must be obtained from Wilson Library at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

caption: Policeman stands over a white student (an onlooker or protest supporter), while tear gas hangs in the air during the Afro-American Society takeover of Duke University's Allen Administration Building.
alt_text: A police office holding a baton stands over a person laying on the ground. Other people and smoke are visible in the background.

caption: Members of the N.C. Highway Patrol and the Durham Police with riot sticks and tear gas gun in hand, stand in front of side entrance to the Allen Building on Duke's west campus.
alt_text: A group of officers wearing gas masks and carrying batons stand together.

caption: William McBroom plays "Black Santa" for the Selective Buying Campaign's alternative Christmas parade, November 29, 1968.
alt_text: An African-American man dressed as Santa Claus sits atop a float. Numerous people are gathered around him.

caption: N.C. Mutual executive R. Kelly Bryant, Jr., tosses lollipops, and Santa Claus (William McBroom) receives onlookers' cheers during a "Black Christmas" parade, November 29, 1968. Sponsored by the Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement as part of its boycott of certain white-owned businesses, the parade was held on Fayetteville Street at the same time as the Durham Merchants Association's traditional parade downtown.
alt_text: A parade with mostly African-American people watching and a float with a black man dressed as Santa Claus.

caption: Lloyd Jacobs, a Durham house painter and "king kleagle" of the Ku Klux Klan, displays his displeasure at what James W. Young, a North Carolina Central University professor, has to say outside Durham City Hall, October 29, 1967.
alt_text: A white man dressed in Ku Klux Klan garb, a black man standing a few feet from him, and a black police officer standing in the background.

caption: Students sleep on the quad during the silent vigil at Duke University.
alt_text: A large crowd of people laying on the ground with blankets and sleeping bags.

caption: Martin Luther King Jr. speaks at White Rock Baptist Church February 16, 1960. His appearance drew a standing-room-only crowd estimated at 1,200, who responded by collecting money for future demonstration expenses.
alt_text: Dr. Martin Luther King preaching in a church. The organ and choir are visible behind him.

caption: Malcolm X (born Malcolm Little), a gifted orator and advocate for radical political action to advance black interests, appeared in Page’s Auditorium on Roxboro Street on April 18, 1963. He debated Durham resident Floyd McKissick, an NAACP lawyer and civil rights activist, before a standing-room-only crowd, roughly 75 percent black and many of whom were students. Originally scheduled at W. D. Hill Recreation Center, the program was moved after city officials canceled the reservation on the grounds that the Black Muslims were not a religious group, as they had stated. McKissick declared that the city “stomped on the first amendment” to the Constitution when it denied the use of the hall for the debate.
alt_text: Malcolm X standing behind a podium.

caption: Martin Luther King, Jr., addresses the Southern Political Science Association at Durham's Jack Tar Hotel November 13, 1964. By that time, King was the best-known leader of and spokesman for the Civil Rights Movement, his efforts rewarded with the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize.
alt_text: Dr. Martin Luther King standing behind a podium at the Jack Tar Hotel.

caption: Martin Luther King, Jr., center, visits the Woolworth's lunch counter in downtown Durham, February 16, 1960. The store had closed the counter after sit-in demonstrations there the previous week. With King are civil rights activist Rev. Ralph Abernathy at left; Rev. Douglas Moore, who led Durham's first sit-in, in 1957 at the Royal Ice Cream Company, right of King; and an unidentified man at far right.
alt_text: From left to right: Reverend Ralph Abernathy, Dr. Martin Luther King, Reverend Douglas Moore and an unidentified black man standing in a store.

caption: Roy Wilkins (left), executive director of the NAACP, joins Durham Attorney Floyd McKissick and James Farmer (right), national director of the Congress of Racial Equality, to protest segregation at Durham's Howard Johnson's Restaurant on August 12, 1962.
alt_text: From left to right: Roy Wilkins, Floyd McKissick, and James Farmer in suits standing outside. A fourth man is standing behind them with his back turned.

caption: Members of National Guard rest in Holt School. They were called in after the death of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Photo taken April 7, 1968.
alt_text: Three white, armed National Guard soldiers seated on a bench. One of them is reading a newspaper.

caption: A crowd estimated at 500 people demonstrates against segregation at Howard Johnson's Restaurant on the Durham-Chapel Hill Boulevard on August 12, 1962. Sunday afternoon protests at the restaurant went on for almost a year, until mass demonstrations in May 1963 led to integration of most eating establishments in Durham.
alt_text: A large group of people gather along the side of a highway outside a Howard Johnson's.

caption: Demonstrators rally at Durham City Hall at the end of a march from Fayetteville Street on April 5, 1968, the morning after Martin Luther King's assassination in Memphis. While the march was peaceful, Durham would erupt in arson the following day, leading city officials to call out the National Guard and impose a curfew to curb further violence and restore order in town.
alt_text: A large crowd of people gathered outside of city hall.

caption: Durham lawyer Floyd B. McKissick and his wife, Evelyn, escort their daughter, Andree, and Henry Vickers to their first day of classes at Carr Junior High School, Sept. 2, 1959.
alt_text: From left to right: Henry Vickers, Floyd McKissick, Andree McKissick, and Evelyn McKissick walk on a sidewalk outside Carr Junior High School.

caption: Tear gas disperses the crowd of onlookers and supporters assembled around Duke's Allen Administration Building during its takeover by Afro-American Society members and supporters.
alt_text: White people running outside with tear gas all around.

caption: A Carolina Theatre manager confronts prospective black patrons in the lobby.
alt_text: Four black men inside a lobby facing a white man with his back to the camera. Other people are visible in the background.

caption: A "round-robin" demonstrator asks to buy a ticket to the Carolina Theatre and gets a refusal at the box office. Once turned away, protestors went to the end of the line and waited their turns to try again.
alt_text: A black woman stands at a ticket counter speaking to a white woman ticket seller. A long line of black people is formed behind her.

caption: An unidentified protestor is confronted by a Durham police officer and Carolina Theatre assistant manager Milo Crawford on March 14, 1962. Demonstrators were advised not to give their names to police for fear of white reprisals.
alt_text: Two black men, a white man, and a white police officer stand near each other.

caption: A line of "round-robin" protesters extends along Manning Place from the Carolina Theatre box office past city hall (now Durham Arts Council Building) March 14, 1962.
alt_text: A long line of black people formed along a sidewalk outside the Carolina Theatre.

caption: The line of "round-robin" demonstrators stretches from the Carolina Theatre box office west along Manning Place, March 15, 1962. Denied tickets, marchers would return to the end of the line and wait for another turn.
alt_text: A long line of black people outside the Carolina Theatre.

caption: Students from North Carolina College (now North Carolina Central University) and Hillside High School demonstrate at city hall on May 18, 1963. Theirs was one of several simultaneous protests in Durham, which continued for four days and led to 850 arrests.
alt_text: A large group of black people stand together, many with their arms in the air. One person holds a sign that says "You have the freedom to vote."

caption: On October 15, 1956, Martin Luther King, Jr., spoke at Hillside High School. A young Baptist minister, King was receiving his first national attention for guiding a boycott of segregated city buses in Montgomery, Alabama. Invited by the Durham Business and Professional Chain as part of its Trade Week festivity, King told his audience, "Doors will be open to you now that were never open in the past. … Be ready for opportunities."
alt_text: Dr. Martin Luther King stands behind a podium. Two other black men can be seen seated behind him.

caption: Flanked by Durham minister Douglas Moore, left, and civil rights activist Rev. Ralph Abernathy, Martin Luther King, Jr., walks along Main Street in Durham for a visit to the closed Woolworth's lunch counter. The man at the far right is unidentified.
alt_text: From left to right: Reverend Douglas Moore, Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Reverend Ralph Abernathy, and an unidentified man walk outside in Durham.

caption: Howard Fuller (on wall) leads demonstrators past National Guardsmen along Peabody Street on their way to a civil rights rally in front of City Hall, in this file photo from July 20, 1967.
alt_text: A group of black people walking outside. Howard Fuller stands on a wall. Three white male National Guard soldiers armed with guns with bayonets stand and watch them.

caption: Organizers Howard Fuller (left) and Ben Ruffin were major figures in late-1960s actions that often focused on gaining black representation on Durham 's policy-making agencies and protesting alleged inequities in managing the city's public housing.
alt_text: Howard Fuller looks over his shoulder while standing with some other men. Other people can be seen in the background.

caption: The crowd assembled in the parking lot of Durham 's police headquarters for the Wallace-for-president rally.
alt_text: A very large crowd of people stands in front of the Durham police headquarters.

caption: Duke students sit in the rain during the Duke University Silent Vigil after Martin Luther King, Jr.'s assassination.
alt_text: A group of people sit on the ground under umbrellas.

caption: Duke students and faculty at campus event after assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.
alt_text: A group of white people stand with arms crossed, holding hands and appear to be singing.

caption: Students sit silently in order lines during Duke student's silent vigil.
alt_text: A large crowd of people sit on a lawn near Duke Chapel.

caption: Community organizer Howard Fuller (right) and an unidentified man sit at the registration table for the Malcolm X Liberation University in Durham, spring 1969.
alt_text: An unidentifed man and Howard Fuller sit behind a table covered in a banner that says "Malcolm X Liberation University."

caption: The Selective Buying Campaign began in July 1968, when an organization called the Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement issued a 15-page memorandum to the Durham Chamber of Commerce and Merchants Association, demanding changes in welfare, housing, and employment policies in the city. The boycott lasted until February 16, 1969.
alt_text: A flyer published by the Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement asking for support for the "Selective Buying Campaign."
attribution: Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement

caption: Northgate Shopping Center, and downtown branches of businesses located there, were the first target of the Black Solidarity Committee's boycott in July 1968. By the middle of August, 14 other firms had been added to its do-not-patronize list as the committee sought to pressure the chamber of commerce and Durham Merchants Association to use their influence on behalf of its demands.
alt_text: A boycott list of stores published by the Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement.
attribution: Black Solidarity Committee for Community Improvement

caption: White ushers block black worshippers (Fay Mayo and fellow NCCU student) at First Baptist Church.
alt_text: A black man and Fay Mayo stand on the stairs outside a church facing two white men.

caption: Campaign manager Nathan Thomas (left) stands with Durham City Council candidate Eugene Hampton, April 1969. Hampton was one of three black candidates for council seats. He lost a runoff to a white incumbent.
alt_text: Two black men stand outside a building pointing at a campaign message printed on the window.
Five black men and women kneel in prayer before a black minister.
caption: The Royal Ice Cream strikers pray before going to court. Participants included Mary Clyburn, Virginia Williams, Rev. Douglas E. Moore, Vivian Jones, Jesse Gray, Claude Glenn, and Melvin H. Willis.  "It was exciting, because we went where we dared not to go. I wasn't frightened or anything of that sort because either way, we could have made history. If he had served us ice cream, he would have made history. But, by refusing to, I guess we made history!" -Virginia Williams, Royal Ice Cream Protester, 2003 Interview

alt_text: A white man with blood dripping down his face holds a bandage to his head. He is helped by another man with other people in the background.
caption: A demonstrator is aided after being struck in the head during demonstration at Duke where students took over the Allen Building on February 13, 1969

alt_text: Four black police officers stand together outside. Another officer stands off to the side.
caption: A still shot from "Negro Durham Marches On" shows four black police officers outside of a building.

alt_text: A large indoor gathering of black men and women. The men are wearing uniforms. One person is seated at a piano, a couple dances, and numerous other people are standing and seated around them.
caption: Black World War II servicemen with hostesses play piano, dance, and talk at the canteen.

alt_text: A black man seated behind a desk reads an issue of the Carolina Times.
caption: Louis Austin, Editor of The Carolina Times.

alt_text: A black police officer is seated in the driver's seat of a police car.
caption: Clyde Cox driving a police patrol car.

alt_text: A group of white men hold their hands on a book and raise their other hands in the motion of taking an oath.
caption: R.N. Harris, First Black Elected to Durham City Council. Mr. Harris was elected to the council in 1953. He was also the first black appointed to the school board, in 1958. The man in the center back of the picture in the light suit is George Watts Carr Jr.

alt_text: A white man sits behind a desk. Another man stands in front of him with several other people seated along the perimeter of the room.
caption: Durham Committee on Black Affairs meets with Luther Hodges, Governor of North Carolina in 1955.

alt_text: Five black men stand and look at a piece of paper.
caption: Conrad Pearson, Hugh Thompson, Floyd McKissick, William G. Marsh, John H. Wheeler, Durham Schools suit lawyers.
